sub_topic: The self-similarity of the Lévy C curve.
message_1: What is the fractal dimension of the Lévy C curve, which is generated by replacing each straight line segment of length 1/3 with two line segments of the same length, where the angle between them alternates between 45 and -45 degrees?
message_2:
To find the fractal dimension of the Lévy C curve, we can use the formula:

D = log(N) / log(s)

where D is the fractal dimension, N is the number of self-similar pieces, and s is the scaling factor.

In the Lévy C curve, each straight line segment of length 1/3 is replaced by two line segments of the same length. So, N = 2.

The scaling factor, s, is the ratio of the original length to the length of the new segments. In this case, the original length is 1, and the new segments have a length of 1/3. So, s = 1 / (1/3) = 3.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

D = log(2) / log(3)

D ≈ 0.6309

So, the fractal dimension of the Lévy C curve is approximately 0.6309.
